text: Great byob spot in the old town area. Fish tasted pretty fresh and they offer a good mix of standard and more creative rolls. Mexican maki, crazy crumb, and the rainbow roll were all good. Also tried the seasonal pumpkin roll which was surprisingly delicious. Restaurant was also good about accommodating one of our parties no-mayo request. Ambiance doesn't provide much but overall its a pleasant and tasty BYOB sushi spot that's better than several others I've tried in the city

I went here for dinner with my husband and if you're expecting Japanese food, you will be disappointed. I would say this is some sort of fusion or Japanese-style food. The tempura was not made with a tempura batter since it didn't have the usual flakiness, but seemed more just like American-style onion ring batter. The chicken teriyaki did not taste like teriyaki and had a bunch of mushrooms over the top. The food tasted okay, but it was just a bit odd and not what we expected at all.

This establishment is one of the better sushi restaurants in Old Town. A little pricey for the regular maki rolls but the food is pretty tasty. The establishment is byob and very casual. So, if you're craving sushi before a turn up on Wells Street I recommend Shiso.

Went in here on a rainy day.  I didn't see any fish in the display case.  That should have been a sign but I was hopeful.  The wait staff seemed friendly and the sushi chefs were nice too.  But when the udon came out and the broth tasted like soy sauce water and the noodles were way over cooked that's when I knew I was in trouble. Instant udon from the store would have tasted better.  Some of the sushi and maki rolls were decent.  The tempura was thick and heavy with no panko flakes. The broccoli tempura looked like it may have been a bit rotten before going in the batter.  Not sure if it would be called tempura at this point.  Hire a chef that can actually cook and maybe your food will actually taste good.  You could not pay me to eat here again.  Absolutely dumbfounded with the four star rating.
Best sushi place we've found in Old Town! The sushi is great and very reasonable for the amount that you get. Love the byob, and have never had to wait for a table!

My favorite sushi in old town! Great service, delicious sushi options, BYOB or purchase there... It has it all. The store is small and could easily be passed over but don't be fooled, the food is delicious and worth the stop! Casual feel inside which I like as well.
Great neighborhood sushi place. Very flavorful and presentation adds to the appetite. BYOB so bring a bottle. If you forget to byob, they also have some good sake on hand. Wasabi is very good here.

Basic. I've been going around the city for weeks looking for katsu curry. I had this place bookmarked to try. I wanted Cocoro but they don't deliver. This place delivered but failed to deliver. (See what I did there?!) It really did taste like something I could make at home. Never again.
We went with a bunch of friends before a Second City show. We were able to make a reservation and BYOB! They were great and the food was delicious. Very good recommendation for a group restaurant.

Great little BYOB place. Emphasis on little-- there are only a few tables! I went with a group of 5 for dinner and was nervous about how loud we seemed. A small venue mixed with BYOB and a large group just seemed like a recipe for disaster! However, the food was excellent. We tried several of the rolls and all were varying shades of delicious, my favorites being the crunchy, spicy tuna roll and and volcano roll.  Service was polite and efficient, and the ambiance was inviting and casual. I don't know if I would bring a *first* date here, given how casual I felt the place was, but this is a great spot for a really tasty sushi dinner.

Big fan of this place! Convenient location, near a brown line stop, relatively easy street parking,  very friendly staff. Intimate, cozy vibe without feeling squished with your next table dining partners. It's BYOB for $3pp and are kind enough to give you a bucket of ice and glassware for your drinks if you want it.  Came because I had a hankering for sushi, ended up getting the chicken katsu with curry, the Tiger roll, and the New York. The chicken katsu with curry came on a bed of rice with a salad on the side. Pretty filled for $15, the chicken katsu was well fried and tender, the Japanese curry was a little on the thick side and a little too sweet. Would've liked some other veggies besides just carrots, but all in all it was pretty tasty. The Tiger roll (fried soft shell crab, avocado, unagi sauce, and more) was pretty delicious. It was topped with a slice of tamago which really balanced out the savoriness with a hint of sweetness, and the unagi sauce with the other herbs put it over the top. The New York roll was surprisingly yummy too - with unagi and cream cheese inside, you could barely taste the unagi with the overpowering flavor of the cream cheese, but I certainly left happy. All in all, might just be my go-to easy sushi joint. If you're looking for high end sashimi or sushi experience, this isn't the place. But if you're looking for a place that everyone will love, this is a great find.

My one love. Shiso has my heart forever and always. Mexican roll has transformed me into an addict for this place.  Solid service as well. I love the ambience and love that it is BYOB. I love you Shiso.

Came here during the week and easily got a table. The menu had some good options but the food was just okay. The tuna tempura appetizer was good but wish they had more raw tuna options.  Overall, it's a good quick sushi spot with good service and big tables for a group setting but with mediocre sushi.

The food here is really tasty.  They have some delicious items that are no longer on the menu because they weren't popular (hello Midori Island roll!) but they still let me order them :) The other thing I love about this place is the care and attention to detail of the staff. Everyone is very friendly - - the second or third time you eat here you will be addressed by name. They are always friendly. I worked in restaurants for nearly 15 years prior to my current career and when the food is consistently good and the staff cares about making you feel like a VIP, you have a winning combo. This place is super busy on Fri and Sat nights so you will need a reservation for those times.  They are BYOB but they also do serve wine so the corkage fee is completely understandable.

I thought this was really good! We picked it because we were nearby tonight. Walked in and sat right now. You can BYOB for $3 per person but we just grabbed drinks there.  Started with spicy miso soup, spicy edamame and some warm house sake. I'm not big on fancy rolls (see: sauces to mask worse quality fish) so we ordered the sashimi platter, hamachi scallion, Alaska (salmon avocado) roll and the roll that had tuna, white tuna, avocado, fish eggs on the special rolls - blanking on the name but yum! We ate it all and the quality was fresh, clean and tasty. It was a Thursday night around 8:30 and very quiet. Still quality and service was good! I recommend this spot if you like the basics of sushi and really want fresh melt in your mouth fish. I plan to be back for some more.
Sushi is always on par. Cozy little atmosphere with very friendly servers. Love this place!
a very cozy sushi place. decent food. nice environment

I visited Shiso for my birthday and it was great. They quickly accommodated six of us and serve us rather promptly. When they noticed we were taking advantage of the BYOB option, they brought over glasses for our beer. We were charged a $3 corkage fee for each person that was drinking but it was still a huge money saver. I got the rainbow roll and it was delicious, not very filling but that's sushi for you. I will definitely be visiting again with the BYOB option.

The food was pretty tasty, although I admit I wish there was a higher number of more basic rolls on the menu. We split 3 signature rolls between 2 people and it was just the right amount of food. BYOB is also nice, although if I'm being charged a corkage fee, it would have been nice to have the wine poured into our glasses and topped off for us.  When I made my reservation, the hostess said I'd need to finish eating by a certain time - first time I've heard that, but thankfully they didn't hold us to it. They seem to run a tight ship with booking tables, which was pretty fascinating.

Visited shiso for the first time this evening for date night! The food and service was great. I ordered the Sears tower Miko, Miso soup, and a beer (didn't BYOB). The miso soup was great although I don't like tofu or spinach I ate around it. The Sears Tower Miko was stacked like a tower and beautifully plated! It was delicious especially with the sauce and was very fresh. Our waitress was very kind and helped with any questions we had regarding the menu. Very small restaurant but got a table right away! Definitely will be returning to try more!

Adorable BYOB ($3 flat fee for corkage per person) sushi place that takes reservations. Also, rolls are well-priced/ lean to the cheaper side.The food was good, service was quick and all of the staff was super friendly! I just wish the place had more seating- but definitely good for a date or a girls dinner out before hitting the bars, especially since it's right next to old town social.
The absolute best sushi place in old town! BYOB is a plus! My faves: - hamachi app - spicy miso - mango tango roll - pumpkin roll  - all the sashimi is amazing
Great sushi in old town. Pretty average prices. Byob. Cute, trendy interior. My favorite is the Mexican roll but all their sushi is very fresh and top notch. I will return no doubt.

I was brought here by the yelp reviews, but I got to say I am a little dissapointed. The fried calamari appetizer was delicious! Crispy and great sauce! When it comes to sushi it was average... It was missing this "yum" moment and I will definitely forget about it soon.

Nice quaint sushi restaurant on North Ave.  VERY small space, but was cozy instead of cramped.  Very friendly and attentive staff. The sushi was above average and better than what I was expecting.  We ordered the fried calamari, miso soup, seaweed salad, a few rolls and sashimi.  The fried calamari was great, crisp on the outside and tender on the inside.  It's very easy to overcook so was very impressed when it wasn't.  Miso soup was basic, not great, not bad.  The seaweed salad was good, but a bit too sweet for my preference.  The rolls were good, the crispy salmon skin was actually crispy! My personal gauge on how good a sushi place is is based on the freshness of the seafood.  I always get the Ikura (salmon roe) and the maguro (tuna).  The ikura was nearly tasteless, which to me is a sign that it isn't fresh.  The maguro was good, but still not the freshest I've had. Overall, it was better than I would have expected from a small neighborhood sushi place.  Can't be too hard on the place since this isn't the Bay Area or LA, but definitely good for the money and location.  Will be going back to check out the Katsu Curry!

We order from Shiso all the time but last night was our first time eating in the restaurant. The staff were friendly and the service was fast. It's a nice, cozy atmosphere inside. Ordering in has its advantages since you get free edamame or house salad for orders of $30 or more. You get a free california roll or spicy tuna maki roll for orders of $50 or more. You also get 10% off all cash orders. Just check the website to confirm the offers are still valid.  I would recommend the spicy miso soup, fried calamari (with a honey wasabi dipping sauce) the chicago roll, and the unakyo roll. While they serve alcohol in the restaurant, remember that you can bring your own for $3 per person.
Tried this for the first time and it was not busy around that time. Affordable bento box prices and the katsu curry was the bomb
Just stopped by as we were walking by very nice spot with good service...definitely try the Sears tower maki and the house saki!
Great customer service, great food, great everything. I recommend the teriyaki chicken meal! You will not be disappointed.

Hidden Gem.  My favorite go-to sushi spot in Chicago.  I live across the street from RA but will still go slightly out of my way for Shiso. The spicy crunchy tuna and the fried soft shell crab are so delicious that I have cravings for them.  I can't say that about a lot of dishes. Best part is its BYOB!!!!  How can you possibly go wrong with that?
Moved to the area recently and this is my go to spot.  Good rolls, fast delivery and the dining room is BYOB.  There was an amazing place in NYC called Cube 63 which reminds me of this gem.

Good sushi place!  Came in on a Monday and the place was empty so the staff was very attentive. Had good creative rolls and good vegetarian maki!! The menu was extremely well priced with miso soup at $2 and rolls around $7.  If you're looking for sushi near old town id recommend this place!
Best byob sushi in Chicago. Service is amazing and sushi is amazing. Definitely go and enjoy the spicy miso soup!!

Visited Shiso on a Saturday night before a Second City show and was a perfect location for that. It was busy when we arrived without a reservation, but they took our number and gave us a call when the table was ready so we could grab a drink next door while we waited, which was nice.  We were seated at the sushi bar, which ended up good bc there were some larger really loud parties doing saki bombs and whatnot, so glad we had seats away from them where we could hear each other.  Food was overall pretty average, nothing bad, but just fairly standard decent sushi. Rolls were pretty small, which wasn't bad for the standard roll price points, but their speciality rolls were probably a bit pricey for the size. They also had a lot of rolls with cream cheese and smoked salmon, which are really the only two ingredients I'll never order in sushi.  Perhaps would be back again if I needed an easy place before a show, but definitely wouldn't go out of my way if I wasn't in the area.
LOVE Shiso - their Agedashi Tofu appetizer is the BEST!  Their seaweed salad, sweet potato fries, sushi are all fantastic - check this place out!

One of my favorite Sushi restaurants in Chicago. I have eaten here a dozen times and have never been disappointed. Fresh fish, beautiful presentation, and great service. The Golden Triangle is a must try along with any of their special Maki's.
Sears tower and volcano. They're a Pontiac game changing play.

Food- 7 Sushi was on point, even fish hating friend enjoyed the Chicago roll. Spicy miso soup very good, good gyoza and shumai.  Shrimp Tempura was crispy and fresh. Atmosphere- 6.5 A little sterile, slightly standardized, and no effort towards authenticity.  Good lighting. Customer Experience- 7.5 Great service, and BYOB is way to go here.

We really enjoyed our meal at Shiso. Started with the Spicy Miso Soup and the Shiso house salad.  Both were pretty good.  My soup came out a few minutes before her salad which was a bit annoying but it wasn't too big of a deal. Next we had the Crispy Calamari appetizer and our first roll was a special Mango Roll topped with Himachi they had that evening.  The Crispy Calamari was a good size appetizer for sharing. We followed up with the Spicy Tuna Roll, Shiso Signature Roll, and the Sears Tower Roll. The Special Maki rolls were really good. Next time around I'll probably stick with the Calamari and Sears Tower and then explore the menu a bit and try some new things.

Hidden Jem of Chicago sushi! This is my absolute favorite place to go for sushi and its fairly close to me which is a huge plus. I'm not that adventurous with sushi but I still enjoy it none the less. I've tried various Maki rolls here and they are all wonderful! I recommend the dragon roll.  The only sad part is that they have added a corkage fee- except for on Sundays. Shiso, I love you and I will be back again and again!

So I'm a fan.  Maybe because it's an unassuming, out of the way little joint, or maybe because I first went based on Yelp reviews, so I was primed to think it was great.  After trying a few different rolls and the edamame every time, I can say I've been pleased with all of them.  While I don't remember which rolls I got, I picked basic ones that weren't overpowered with cream cheese and tempura (because those ones are good ANYWHERE). I'm not sure on the BYOB situation at this point because I've ordered wine each time I've gone, but I heard or read that it's BYOB, so they may still allow that.

A hidden gem in the North Avenue barren strip from Clark to Halsted.  The only sushi in the area.  Open for lunch on Sundays. I LIKE... BYOB on Sundays and NO corkage fee. Drinks List (less than $10) -- Red, White, Beer and Cocktails. Spring Summer Role ($12.95) -- all my favorite ingredients for nourishment and healthy eating.  Greens.  Avocado.  Fresh Fish.  Rice.  The sliver of mango is perfect for just citrus taste to maki. Wasabi Shumai ($6.95) -- wasabi adds a kick and dimension to the sometimes bland and boring Shumai.  Overpriced. SKIP... Sake ($7-21) -- it seems like retail pricing plus markup, not bulk rate. Soft Shell Crab ($6.50) -- the price is right but the single serving crab is itty bitty.  Overcooked. Banana Tempura + Green Tea Ice Cream ($6.95) -- wrong kind of banana for frying.  Overripe mushy banana.  Eek.  A baseball size serving of pre-molded green tea ice cream that was re-frozen.

Lately, I've been hearing the term "comfort food" thrown around rather recklessly. I get it, we're trying to steer away from the fancy-edible-art-gastronomic types of meals and back to our familial roots. Believe me, if there's anyone that can appreciate using food as a coping mechanism, it's me. However, when you have the lethal combination of multiple panic attacks and a laundry list of favorite foods as I do... everything kind of turns into comfort food doesn't it? Professionally, I don't condone eating your feelings with clients...but personally, I say have at it.  So what does comfort food have to do with Shiso? A little dish called katsu curry, my friends. Ah yes, nothing like having a big slab of lightly breaded pork on a bed of fluffy white rice topped with thick curry gravy. Shiso has a reasonably priced katsu curry with a pretty large portion, perfect for dinner and then lunch when you're frustrated at work the next day.  "Oh, you screwed up my paperwork while I was gone for the weekend? I got katsu curry, no f__ks are given."

I'm very loyal to my sushi place in NYC but this was incredible! The shumai is honestly the best I've ever had. And I'm crazy about a BYOB (they actually do sell alcohol, also!) The rolls were also amazing-- I had the Mexican and the spicy tuna, and they were so so good. It was really affordable and our server was so kind and attentive! That said: the special rolls can really add up fast, so be careful if you're on a budget! That said, it's totally worth it :)
Service was very fast and courteous. Everything was delicious especially the spicy tuna maki, salmon yokisoba and spicy shrimp udon

I'm confused by all the great reviews. Went here for dinner recently and was unimpressed. Freshness is important in a sushi restaurant, and nothing here was fresh. Wilted brown lettuce in the salads, dried-out California rolls that seemed to have been premade and refrigerated for a long time, so-so maki rolls. Our glassware was dirty and there were fruit flies buzzing around the table. Also if you're planning to BYOB there's now a $3 per person corkage fee.

Awesome restaurant with well priced sushi. The service and hospitality of the employees makes this a great place for date nights or a night out with friends. Also byob is available, however they just started offering alcohol with a bar.

Sincerely my favorite sushi place in all Chicago. SO good! Tucked away on North Ave in Old Town, Shiso can comfortably hold about 30 guests. It's a BYOB restaurant, which is always fantastic. If you forgo bringing your own bottle of wine, you can order one for a reasonable price ($20) at the restaurant.  Shiso makes super yummy and creative sushi rolls. My favorites, in order: 1. Sears Tower-- OH MY WORD. I could eat like five of these in one sitting. The whole has cream cheese, crab, clinator, asparagus, and unagi. Then it's deep fried, stacked up to look like a tower, and then drizzled with sweet sauce. Seriously, heavenly. A MUST TRY. 2. Mexican -- deep fried shrimp, avaocado, masago, jalapeno, and cilantro, covered with unagi sauce. I am not a fan of spicy food, but this is amazing.  3. Tiger -- deep fried soft shell crab, cucumber, avocado, cilantro, masago mayo, topped with tamago and unagi sauce. So yummy. The waitresses are always super friendly and nice. They don't mind if you're there for a long, just hanging out and catching up with friends. The bill is always pretty decent too! If you're going with a group, I'd recommend calling ahead for a reservation, as space is tight and it's usually pretty busy.  BONUS -- they also deliver!!!  Whenever I'm in Chicago, I always stop in at Shiso!

Definitely a must for girls night! Great for dine in and take out. The only thing I would not recommend as a to go item is the seaweed salad. The dressing weighs it down significantly by the time it arrives. Tons of vegetarian options as well! I recommend the Super Veggie Tempura roll.

I'm not sure why this place has 4 stars. Nothing I tasted here was worthy of that, including the Sashimi Set, the Spicy Udon with Chicken, and the Sunset Roll. Sashimi Set - Average, nothing special. Not especially fresh. Spicy Udon with Chicken - The spicy sauce, drenched all over the noodles, was too creamy for my taste. It made the consistency almost like an alfredo spaghetti, which was weird because I always expect (and prefer) Japanese udon to be much lighter. Sunset Roll - Meh, very average. Also, It took us forever to even find a roll amongst the Specialty Rolls that didn't have cream cheese in it... clearly indicating that this is not a traditional Japanese restaurant - cream cheese in sushi is one trend I've never understood. Definitely go elsewhere for Japanese food... Sunshine Cafe, Uni Sushi, Union Sushi, Arami, etc. There are a ton of better options!

Pretty decent sushi place for the price. We had the volcano, tiger, Chicago and spicy tuna rolls which were fresh, good blends and depth of flavors. The sashimi pieces I will skip next time. Polite and timely wait staff. Good cocktail selection (lychee martini is great!) Overall a good experience and we'll deforest return!
Nothing special, but a solid Bento box. A lot of food...too much for lunch.

How did this little gen escape me for all these years?  It's probably because Shiso, with it's unassuming facade sits a little off the beaten path on North Ave just a little west of Sedgewick. I actually drove right by the place and had to turn around and go back.  There is plenty of street parking right out front which makes this place a breeze to visit.  Another plus?  It's BYOB so you can enjoy your favorite beverage with no corkage fee. We went with about 8 people (make reservations as this place is small) and the team here did a great job with our large party. The sushi was fresh and delicious, the rolls were innovative (ask about what the chef's special is of the day and then order one of them) and the space is intimate and cute. And best of all?  The prices are reasonable. Next time you are looking for great sushi- really take a look . . .and you might find Shiso on North Ave.

My fiancé and I have made Shiso our regular weekend date-night spot. We have been coming to Shiso for months now and we have never been let down. The fish is always fresh and the sushi is rolled consistently. Service is always top-notch and amazing. We have been to some of the top sushi restaurants in Chicago and Shiso, while more casual, matches the quality and the service with a much more reasonable price tag.  Thus far, our favorites include calamari and edamame as an appetizer (best calamari in the city!), miso soup, spicy tuna, jala colar, negi hamachi, and the mochi ice cream for desert. Cannot beat the BYOB! Highly recommend, you will not disappointed!

Truly one of the best sushi spots in the city. It's small and quaint, and really conveniently located a few blocks from the Sedgewick brown line stop. Prices are very reasonable and the menu has a little bit of everything (including some awesome supreme rolls). The calamari is perfect, and the wasabi mayo is crazy delicious. The sashimi is delicious and fresh, and all of the rolls I've tried have been great.  Highly recommend!

Visiting from Miami and happened to walk by. Stopped in late on a Sunday and it was quiet but the staff was welcoming. Ordered several rolls and they came right out. Very fresh and delicious even at closing time. Looks like a spot I would eat at very often in Miami. Prices were good and I have no complaints on this trip. Great random dinner.

Great little sushi gem.  The pieces have gotten smaller but the appetizers are pretty amazing.  Love the calamari, tempura tuna roll.  Sushi pieces are fresh.  This place could go from good to great if they served bigger pieces and cuts of fish!

Best sushi I have had in a long time! Chicago maki roll and Volcano were my favorites. Friendly service and the food came quick. Cute and warm atmosphere. It is BYOB (they serve liquor, too) but have a $3 corkage fee. Will definitely be back!
Love this place! The food has been excellent over multiple visits. Wait-staff is always attentive and friendly. Prices are reasonable.

Good sushi.i listened to all the comments below about how great sears tower roll is and i tried it.for me it was overfried.i really liked the chicago roll and shiso special roll.service is nice and fast but be prepared to wait for at least 15 min even if you have reservation.

Cute little sushi place in Old Town. Not sure if it's byob but they still serve alcohol there. We didn't have a reservation on a Friday night but they were able to squeeze us in a tiny corner table as long as we ate in less than an hour and a half. Worked for us, since we were in a time crunch. Service is friendly and the food is quick. The mexican roll was our favorite. Something about jalapeños in sushi is just genius. We also got the Sears tower roll and the shisu signature roll. Both are so tasty, smothered in all that unagi sauce and spicy mayo. Yum.

Came in on a Saturday afternoon for lunch. The place was empty, but I saw good reviews and decided to give the place a chance. The Sears tower roll we ordered was good, but the sashimi was pretty horrid. The tuna was really, really dry. Salmon and hamachi texture was weird...it was as if they were recently thawed out. Yuck.

This place could be in the running for best sushi in Old Town.  The fish was absolutely fresh and the cuts were delicious.  Even the yellowtail had been trimmed so it didn't have that unsightly and in my mind distasteful fatty layer.  BYOB or I guess you can buy your own as well.  I will come back regularly.
My friend and I got the Sears Tower Roll, Philadelphia Roll, and I think the Chicago roll? Anyway, it was all good! Kind if expensive though. The waitress was nice. The place was nice looking.

The food here is somewhat expensive. The quality is quite average. It is not BYOB anymore and they do charge a corkage fee. The maki rolls are tiny and they are quite stingy with the sashimi. It's just not worth the visit. But one plus is that we have made a reservation and they did have a table for us straightaway, despite being such a small restaurant.

Delicious sushi and great decor. Perfect for a date. Try the spicy miso for a new twist to an old standby. Noodles are average, but everything else makes up for it. And it helps that this consistent place is on my block.

This place hadn't been on my radar as far as sushi joints until I dined here last weekend with a girlfriend. I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. The sushi was very fresh, service was attentive but not overly so, and prices were very reasonable especially for the area. BYOB always helps my enjoyment level as well. We got two speciality rolls which were awesome, an eel and cucumber (my all time favorite thing) and it was one of the best I've had. The only dud was the Seattle roll.  I would definitely come back here when in the area.

Solid little sushi spot for a quick bite. Was in there last night, had the house salad, spicy tuna and the Golden Triangle Roll.  Overall the food was very good. The house salad is the traditional greens with ginger dressing, their ginger dressing is more sweet than other places I have been to. Spicy tuna was great and the Golden Triangle was good and is promising, but there is just too many sauces on it, and too much of them. It makes the roll, which has tempura shrimp in it to start, very heavy in your stomach... Not exactly what I was going for. But I will be back, great that it is right around the corner!

I was a big fan of this little BYOB sushi place. Things I loved: The Seaweed Salad  By far one of the best seaweed salads I've had in the city Shiso signature roll: Amazing Spicy cruncy tuna was great too. Things I would improve 1. The atmosphere was slightly bland.  Tone the slights down slightly and change the music to fit the restaurant a little better.  FOOD IS SOOOO GOOD. 2. Benches were hard Other than that loved this place and I went on a weekday, so maybe on the weekends packed with people the atmosphere would be perfect, still felt the lights were a little high and CANDLES would have been a great improvement.  Why do candles make things so intimate?  Something esoteric about fire.

Nice little sushi place, skip the sashimi sets. We were looking for a good sushi place and we found one. We got their crispy shrimp rolls and a sashimi supreme. Each piece of sushi 2 - 2.75, which is pretty average.  Miso soup- salty.  Shrimp rolls- impressed by the one long piece of shrimp in each, but needed a little salt. Sashimi supreme had 15 pieces ($26)- These things are always grab bags. Some are good and some are meh. All the pieces were fresh, and the white tuna was the best. The shoestring radish that the sashimi lay on was a little too much, like a tumbleweed and a rather flavorless.  Oddly, the fish on the sushi and sashimi were same size. Given that the set repeated fish. It might have been better to chose 10 individual pieces rather than the 15 piece supreme.  Ambiance and Service 4/5 Food 4/5 Value 3/5

I love you Shiso. Had Mike's birthday celebration here, and we sure did celebrate!  BYOB, wonderful sushi, great friends and atmosphere. Success. We'll be back Shiso, hopefully sooner rather than later!

I usually go to Tokyo 21 for my Spicy Tuna Roll, but decided to try something new today.  I pulled.up the reviews and decided to try this place out because it has a 4/5 stars.  I wasn't sure if they were open because there was nobody else there. I ordered miso soup ($1.50), spicy tuna roll ($6), and their Plum Saki wine ($6).  They filled my wine glass to the rim, which was nice, and the wine itself was very unique. However, the sushi was just ok. It was plain, with nothing extra...just filling and rice. As soon as I left I called Tokyo 21 and ordered a spicy tuna roll to go. I couldn't end my night with just "ok" sushi...and the kicker-it's $1 more than Tokyo 21. I hate giving poor reviews, but I know that I wasted my $ going there and if someone is checking them out on here I want them to know the truth.

Just received the takeout tempura bento from Shiso. You can order through Seamless, and it actually came fairly quickly, definitely ahead of schedule. Everything was packaged neatly and clean--no leaks or soggy paper bags here. The bento came with 3 delicious dumplings, 3 pieces of a Cali roll, salad, rice, and tempura--delicious, and huge! I will totally order from them again.

The service and ambiance was good, but the price (for dinner) did not match with the quality of the dishes. We got a few rolls of sushi and sashimi for dinner. The portions were smaller than my experience with other sushi restaurants, and their overall quality did not impress. One of my pet peeves is when miso soup isn't included for customers, and when restaurants serve sashimi with rice. While it isn't uncommon to see this, I can't help thinking that it's a business' way to make you pay for soup (which is cheap to make) or use less sashimi for an expensive dish. There are cheaper food (and sushi) options out there. That said, if you are someone big on service and environment, the noise level was low, the decor and furniture are slick and modern, and the waitress was extremely nice.

I live down the street so based upon proximity and the positive Yelp reviews I have given this place three shots.  Each time I have been disapointed with the food.  I tried sushi on the first two occassions and it was very bland compared to a lot of other places I have been to in the city.  This week I ordered a steak teriyaki Bento Box and my girlfriend got the hibachi shrimp thinking that maybe other things on the menu might be better.  Wrong.  We both commented that the only thing that was good was the miso soup.  I just can't understand why people rave about this place on Yelp.  I will say that the service is great and the ambiance is good in the restaurant.

Went there for Sunday lunch and it was empty. Not a very good sign but it was too late to back out the door. Service was excellent, but when we were the only customers, I'd think that it's pretty hard to neglect our needs.  Food: - Miso was very good. It was a good portion too. - takoyaki (octopus puff): delish!!! perfectly battered, perfectly juicy inside and perfectly flavored.  - Shumai: Our Japanese native friend said this was authentic to what shumai tasted like in her memories. I prefer the Chinese version with yellow skin.  - volcano: looks exactly what it sounds like and tastes pretty similar too when you picture ingredients exploding everywhere and mixing together. It was pretty meh for me but when we ordered we knew it was not going to be a roll that you could taste the different layers in. - shiso signature: i had high expectations for this since it was a signature dish. I ended up liking my friend's roll better. Note to self: whenever there are the words "deep fried" in a roll description, do not order, unless you are hungover. - sakura (i think): either sakura or whatever roll that has the least amount of condiments/sauces in the description. The fish was fresh and the amount of avacado was just enough to help the food slide into your esophagus. - sears tower: kudos to the restaurant for keeping it sears towers instead of Willis tower. Taste-wise, I could care less coz the presentation was just priceless. We came up with various interpretations of what they looked like. You'll have to see it for yourself.  The 3-star rating is biased since I didn't try their sashimi or nigiri. But it likely won't bump it up.

Great overall experience at Shiso. Fast and attentive service. BYOB and a great selection of Sushi Rolls. Extremely enjoyable experience. Pretty small restaurant but otherwise was a pretty and trendy atmosphere. Very quiet in the restaurant. The sushi rolls are all extremely delicious and unique. I ordered the Dragon Roll and the Volcano Roll both were very good choices. Very filling and good experience.
Their sushi is OK- not at all memorable.  If it wasn't up the street, I'd prob order from somewhere else.  To be fair, I've never eaten in the restaurant so I'm not sure how that would factor in.

No corkage on BYOB. They take reservations on Open Table, helpful since it is a small spot... Sushi is great and really a good bang for your buck. Menu isnt huge but all the basics are covered. This is the best BYOB Sushi in the area (I live in Old Town)... It really runs laps around Cafe Sushi on Wells.

I expected a better setting from all of the previous reviews, but it's a basic hole-in-the-wall sushi spot. The sushi is great, but the decor is really average. it's BYOB so that is always fun. It's funny because I am pretty sure in the entire restaurant there was one 1-2 male patrons. Definitely a girls night spot since it's not very romantic.

I dinned at Shiso with my husband and another couple for dinner.  I am glad we made a reservation because it is a small restaurant, and all tables were full.  I love that it was BYOB, but I've had better sushi.  It's a great spot to eat before hitting up the night life in Old town.

Decided to give this place a try because it was a 2 minute walk from my apartment. The menu made everything sound good. I won't draw this out. Edamame: stale. Sushi Rolls: Badly rolled. Tiger had weird textured, bad tasting shell on crab. Califorinia was mushy. Next time I will just walk the 5 extra minutes down to Kamahachi.

For the life of me I will never understand how this place survived while Mizu down the street went out of business. The fish here was awful. I have never tasted salmon that tasted so fishy and old in a sushi place.  The staff is friendly enough, but the sushi was so bad.  This is a small place and it was empty...should have been my first clue. Perhaps those on a budget like the BYOB aspect, but I just don't GET how this place outlasted Mizu.  It is not inexpensive, it is boring inside and the fish was not fresh.

My friends & I chose to go back to Shiso last weekend for our reunion. The long table was reserved for our party when we arrived and the staffs greeted us so friendly. We still ordered our favorite rolls and a bunch of sashimi. Fishes are so fresh and delicious. My japanese friend kept on talking about their fishes and he told us he can touch their best fish from his 1st bite. We love their crunchy munchy pumpkin and latin so much! Overall, warm services and great food...while we can enjoy the BYOB too. Thank you so much Shiso!!! You made us a wonderful night!
A lot of great choices for special makis, great prices, BYOB, good attentive and quick service and they do not rush you out. What else do you need?! Been here twice, and I will be returning.

I tried calling for a rsvp for my bday.  They said for a party of 8 I need to give them my credit card to hold.  I asked what they would charge if i'm late.  The girl refused to answer my question and talks to her manager about the credit card.  Then she returns to the phone and tells me that she no longer has 7:30pm available and that I have to come before 6pm.  She totally made that up.  Had it not been a BYOB place, I don't think I would have even considered it.

I was looking for the top-rated sushi joint in Old Town, and Yelp pointed me to Shiso. My friend and I walked in to a completely empty restaurant around 3:30 on a Sunday. Not to be deterred, the space was small and the decor kitschy-minimalist. It reminded me of a lot of the small sushi restaurants on North Clark, if you're familiar. The waitress was quick, pleasant, and as attentive as we'd want throughout the meal. We ordered 4 rolls: Volcano, Red Dragon, Mexican, and seasonal Crunchy Munchy Pumpkin (!).  They were really good! I was expecting some a-ok rolls but these were a solid step above and were consumed enthusiastically. The fish was fresh and the rolls creative, especially the pumpkin one. The Volcano was probably my favorite, since I love unagi sauce and the textural component that the tempura crumbs added. I noticed that they have a lot of cooked rolls, so if you're a non-raw eater then you may enjoy the selection at Shiso.

We came here for a late lunch because the Yelp ratings were very good.  However I don't agree with the consensus. Service was very warm, but the fish here wasn't as fresh as I'm used to back home in Los Angeles. We placed our orders and our server brought miso soup for us.  It was a bit salty for me (due to my palate, not Shiso), so I gave mine to my friend.  Our food came out fast: Spicy Tuna Tempura - spicy tuna and cream cheese, wrapped in seaweed and deep fried, served with ponzu.  A small portion, albeit with good flavor and a nice crispy outside Sashimi Deluxe - we each got this 9 piece chef's choice sashimi.  It was artfully presented, but our server didn't tell us what was what, the pieces were small and thin, and it was lacking a certain fresh glow that I know the freshest fishes have. Salmon sashimi - sashimi here is ordered by the piece, so we got 4 pieces.  It was on the lean side (not a plus in my book), and thin, small-ish pieces. I was not only disappointed with the quality of the fish here, but I could not believe that they didn't have Toro or Ankimo at all. This may be the kind of sushi place that pleases roll eaters, so if that's you, this could still be your kinda place.  For me, a pristine sashimi eater, however, it's not my  kinda place. I regret to say that for $50-ish (before tip), I feel like we could have gotten way better sashimi elsewhere.

Came here for a friend's birthday dinner and we had a party of 16 people, so we basically took up most of the restaurant since there were like 5 little tables left in the whole restaurant. We chose this place because of the convenience factor as it was located close to where we were coming from, but we left a tad dissapointed. The sushi was mediocre at best and left us feeling blah afterwards. From the city maki rolls, to a few special ones, they were all just a okay. The only pluses is that it is byob and it wasn't loud (or maybe we were just the big, loud party) but we could hear everyone and have a perfect conversation over booze and a-okay sushi.  The service gets an additional star because they brought out the rolls super fast, I almost wish that the quality could have been as good as how fast things were coming out. Everyone was happy that they weren't hungry for long, they also didn't mess up anyone's order which is also a good thing. I didn't like that they charged us for additional sauce like spicy mayo or eel sauce, and it's fine I get some places do this, but it would have been nice to let us know beforehand. Overall, prolly won't be back since there are soo many yummier places with just as good service like coast, seadog, etc.

I can't say enough good things about this place! The service has always been excellent but even more so, the food is to die for. I come here at least once every 2 weeks with either my girlfriends or my boyfriend and we always have a good time. I have yet to find a roll I don't like. My favorites in order are: 1. GOLDEN TRIANGLE. It's a party in your mouth. Particular favorite if you like cream cheese. 2. Volcano. Spicey goodness.  3. Latin.... crisp. Almost refreshing-- my boyfriend doesn't like all the sauces and cream cheese and this is his favorite.  4. Spring Summer roll. This is their special right now and it is so yummy. BYOB, reasonably priced and intimate. Also, I start every meal off with their spicey miso soup... best I've had in the city. A++ Shiso!

So I had a friend in town who wanted to have some sushi and then hit North Ave beach. After some serious yelp investigations, we decided to try Shiso. In hindsight, we should have stopped for some supermarket sushi instead.  If I can describe Shiso in one word, I would say it is boring. Our waitress was boring, and we ordered 5 boring rolls. 4 "city maki" rolls, and a "dragon roll". You know a sushi place is not good when the California roll is the best tasting roll, and you feel umm...the "safest"...eating that roll. The worst roll by far was the Philadelphia roll - it took a little bit too long to chew it and it just did not taste right. I couldn't tell if it was the heavy cream cheese or the fish causing this strangeness, but I was sketched out nonetheless. Not what I'm looking for in sushi. The dragon roll was topped with eel, but tasted like sardines. It was so bad that we had to take the eel off the roll to eat it.  We were both very confused that this place earned more stars on yelp than other Sushi places in the area. In the act of full disclosure we went at 4:00PM on a Sunday....maybe they get their fish deliveries on a Monday and we were at the end of the line? Who knows, but I'm not going back to find out.

After living on Old Town for 2 years, I decided to give Shiso a try... On my last day as an Old Town resident. D'oh!!! I came here today for lunch. It was empty since I had a late lunch at 330 pm. It was nice. Peaceful and quiet. The space seems very small so I would rather have the peace and quiet than deal with other peoples conversations.  Anyway. Since I was by myself I didn't go crazy with the order. I orderd several nigiris: Nama sake, escolar, and hamachi. The escolar was so good, I ordered another piece. Also ordered a maki, the Shiso Signature. Usually I am not a fan of cream cheese in my sushi but this was pretty good, all the ingredients balanced out. I wish I came here much earlier. I only lived 1.5 blocks away. This will be my go-to place if I'm ever hanging out at Old Town. Delicious sushi and the price won't feel like ur being ripped off, since the quality of the food is good. Highly recommended!

Ordered the chicken bento box for delivery.  I couldn't eat the chicken.  It smelled like it had been warmed up five or six times already. Also, the sushi was packed with warm food, so it was warm, too. They did offer to refund the price of the chicken dish, but I still wouldn't go back

Tucked away on North Ave is a little place called Shiso.  I say little, because whether you want to or not, you are sharing your table with the people next to you.   By accident or by choice, I've eavesdropped on many conversations at my favorite sushi restaurant.  The best was a guy, who clearly misrepresented himself on his online dating pictures because the girl he was with was waaaaaay out of his league, talking about his walk out basement of his frat house in college.  She wanted nothing to do with the conversation.  However, the two took advantage of the no corking fee BYOB, and by the end of the night, were tongue deep in each others soy sauce. Something is magical about the food and the atmosphere here.  The waitresses always talk to me using my first name, and they don't mind when I'm the last person to leave.  Numerous times they clean every table in the restaurant, making it clear they want to go home, but never rush me.  What a place!

I don't think I can say one bad thing about this place. Went with a few friends right before a show around 730 and was able to get a table for 5 people. I would recommend making reservations using Open Table as the place is small and does get packed. Great ambience for a small restaurant and the food is really good! The service is excellent and the best thing is that the place is BYOB friendly...Definitely will return back again.

My go to for sushi every time. My only problem is, deciding what to get. The sumo roll, sears tower, the mexican roll, the golden triangle... The list goes on. They are all amazing. I have recommended shiso to several people, and they are all returning customers. Their everyday rolls; like the spicy tuna or california, are priced appropriately. Then you have the more expensive rolls, that are worth every penny.

A pretty solid little spot.  Clean, white decor and friendly, quick service.  We had the spicy tuna roll, the boston roll, and the latin roll, all of which were quite tasty, and felt extremely fresh.  The seaweed salad and shumai were also excellent.  Definitely a good place to know about.

I have no choice but to bump Shiso up to 4 stars: came in for probably the 6th time last week and the quality of the sushi continues to far outperform my petty differences with the close quarters and sometimes spotty service. The most brilliant thing is that while there are certainly opportunities to order $12-15 maki, there are a number of VERY good options at the $7-9 range as well (crunchy spicy tuna & mexican are my 2 personal favs in this category). I've added two rolls to my top 5 so I'll just mention those here:  Mango Tango: crab, mango, sweet potato tempura, avocado, topped with hamachi, spicy mayo, and green onion. As delicious as the ingredients make it sound Mexican: deep fried shrimp, cilantro, avocado, jalapeno, unagi. I'm a sucker for maki with textural contrast, but this one knocks it out of the park for $7. On a side note: the service was MUCH stronger on a weeknight compared to my previous weekend forays. Corkage is still free. Really learning to love this place.

Was meeting friends here for dinner on a Saturday night. They arrived at 7pm and my buddy and I wanted to wait til the end of the NCAA final 4 game before we came, we were right down the street. We arrived casually late around 7:40pm. The whole time, I was getting repeated text messages asking whether we were coming or not. Because of the limited amount of tables at Shiso, the restaurant was demanding to know because they were threatening to take away our reserved tables for other customers. Yes, we were coming. We were late, it happens. Chill out, Shiso. This wasn't the only rude thing about the staff. Our party was told that we had to be gone by 8:30pm because of another reservation. Really? Sorry if we are inconveniencing you by trying to give you our business.  We showed up late and promptly order our rolls to split between 2 of us. We were hungry and ordered a healthy amount. We were slightly intoxicated already, so I imagine anything would have tasted good, but every roll we ordered was exceptionally good. Beer goggles for the stomach?  The Shiso Signature was good. I'm not a fan of maki with cream cheese but I didn't think there was an overpowering taste. Jalapeno was not too spicy and a nice touch. Tokyo Tower was also very very good. Fried Asparagus inside was a nice crunch and spicy shrimp on top was delicious. Seaweed salad inside as well. This was my favorite. The Volcano was also good. Hamachi inside with avocado and masago with delicious sauces. Also very good but you're basically paying $14 for the sauces on top. We added another roll but I forgot because I had been drinking for 7+ hours at this point.  Our bill for 2 of us was a healthy $80 for our 30 minutes of enjoyment (guess that happens when you let me order while intoxicated with no parameters on price). The 8:30pm reservation was hovering over our table by that time so we finished up our bottles and continued the night elsewhere.  Overall, 4 stars for food, 2 stars for service. I got the impression (and from other reviews) that this place is great for a date of 2 people and not for bigger groups because of the limited space. I'll give them another chance, hopefully not so intoxicated but no promises.

This sushi place was just OK. I feel like opinions on the best sushi places differ across the board though. My friend said this place is one of her favorites, but I disagree. It's average. And the server brought two wrong orders so that doesn't help the review any.

My friend and I decided to go to the nearest suchi restaurant, aside from Friend's Suchi. We saw Shiso's reflets about its delivery service in our mailboxes the other day, and off we went. The manager is Thai. She welcomed us warmly and gave suggestions on the menu. We ordered its lunch special: 5 pieces of suchi (tuna, white fish, shrimp, salmon, and another thing I didn't remember) and california maki. The fish on suchi is fresh and delicious, but I felt very so so for the california maki. Then we order three more of its special maki. We really love Volcano and Golden Triangle. Shiso signature is also good but not on top of the latter two. It's around 70 net for two persons. Not too expensive. In sum, yes it's not bad overall.

NO WAY will I ever go here. I called about two weeks in advance to make a reservation for my Birthday. 8 people. The lady took forever to give me a yes or no answer, told me it gets busy and then asked to call me back after she spoke with her manager. First of all, I am aware that it gets busy that is why I called way in advance to make sure I could get a table. Second, Cant you just look and see if there is an opening or not? She called me back about 2 hours later and said "No we cant take you". No other time options....nothing. Wow...Seems to me they don't know how to run a business. They should have taken a table of 8 people than keeping those tables open just to fill up.  That's ok though since I can think of a handful of other sushi joints I would rather go to. Way to do business you knuckle heads.

I've no been here 3 times and have had a fantastic experience each time. The sushi is fresh and fast and the edamame is spot on. It's never been crowded, but I always go for lunch and always go early. I've also ordered carry out and still just as good. So glad this is close to my new office!

Everything I ordered or tasted was delicious.  I ordered: Mexican Roll New York Roll x2 Philadelphia Roll Crunchy Spicy Tuna I also got to taste some of the special rolls that my roommate couldn't finish and all were great.  BYOB w/ no corkage fee... also a plus!  decor and service pleasant enough. If you don't eat much or just want a sushi appetizer.... then this place is great.  But do NOT go hungry.  All the regular rolls I ordered where very small.  My roommate and I debated going to get a Wells burger as a 2nd dinner as we were both still really hungry after the first round.   Instead, I ordered another 2 rolls and she 1, so once you throw in tax and tip and you're at $50 each, which is more than I like to spend on an everyday dinner.  So, I consider this trip a treat and will have to stick  to AYCE places for my sushi binges.

I come from Reno (the land of deep fried, all you can eat sushi for cheap) and have been trying to find some decent sushi in Chicago that I don't have to pay $12 - $15 a roll for. We ordered through their website (received 10% off the first order), and the expected time was 1 hour. The delivery took about half that time, and picking up the food from downstairs, the delivery guy was friendly and nice! The miso soup was warm and delicious. The rolls were pretty delicious as well; I had one with cilantro that was awesome, and I ordered a couple more rolls with shrimp and avocado. Best sushi I've found so far in Chicago :)

I took my girlfriend to Shiso for Valentine's Day and I must say it was a very nice little place. We ordered Edamame for an appetizer and 5 maki rolls for our main course. - Crunchy Munchy Pumpkin Maki (Awesome!) - New York City Maki (Very Good) - Midori Island (ehh probably wouldn't order again) - California (Standard) - Crunchy Spicy Tuna (Pretty bland and boring) After we were finished we were still hungry so actually wound up ordering another of the Pumpkin Maki. They surprised us with a special Red Velvet cupcake for dessert which was a nice unexpected surprise. Even though it was kind of expensive I would highly recommend the Crunchy Munchy Pumpkin Maki roll if you plan on giving Shiso a try.

My boyfriend surprised me on Valentine's day and took me to a dinner here.  Our reservation was for 7 and I am glad we had one because this tiny placed filled up quite quickly.  Lots of lovebirds enjoying some BYOB sushi on V-day.  We brought a bottle of white wine and started with the staple edamame.  We ordered 5 rolls - the crunchy spicy tuna (bland and not spicy at all), the New York which was very good, the California which was also good, the Midori Island which was interestingly good and the special which was the crunchy munchy pumpkin maki -ebi, pumpkin tempura, crispy Japanese fresh radish, kampyo (sweet marinated squash), spicymayo and topped with fresh salmon, tempura crimp, masago and unagisauce.  This roll was unreal, we actually ordered another because we couldn't get enough and wanted to lick the plate clean when we were done.  The service was slow but I doubt they were used being so crowded.  It didn't matter to us because we were in no rush and were just enjoying our wine when we finished eating.  Each table got a complimentary red velvet cupcake which was unreal.  So good.  Shiso was surprisingly really good and can't beat that it's walking distance from my apartment.

My boyfriend and I came here on a double date with friends and were wowed. While the restaurant is smallish and it can be cold when the door is opened, the food won me over. Shiso is easily accessible via the CTA Brown Line and is right next door to Old Town Social. When we arrived, our friends had already snagged a table - a feat for a Saturday night.  We started with Miso and edamame. Both were excellent and how they should be at a good Japanese restaurant. We then moved on to sushi. We ordered so many rolls I don't remember which exactly, but we also ordered sashimi too. The fish was fresh all around and I recall being wowed by the pumpkin crunch something something something roll. I don't normally take to those types of rolls, but it was insanely tasty!   Shiso is also BYOB, so naturally we brought several bottles of wine and a few six packs- probably more than the limit, but they didn't stop us. The service was good and also attentive but not over bearing.  I will go back and I absolutely look forward to it!

One of my friends raved about Shiso so we decided to have dinner here before a night out on the town. We were able to make a last-minute reservation for three on a Saturday night. I can't recall all the rolls we ordered, but everything was delicious! Our one friend is terrified of sushi and loved his (cooked) rolls! This is a nice little place to go on a date or with friends. It's affordable and BYOB which is always a plus in my book!
Really good sushi for a reasonable price. Very small and intimate setting. It's byob too!

Love this quaint little place. Its steps from my office which makes a lunch decision easy. Miso not too salty and very tasty. There rolls are fresh and they have such a nice selection. I cant wait to come back here and try more. By that time I can give you a more detailed review.

Lately, I have been to sushi restaurants where the presentation and techniques have been disappointing. Dining at Shiso was quite refreshing since it's been awhile coming across a place that pays attention to so much detail. From the place settings, interior decorating, service, to the food itself, everything was handled with care and attention.  We ordered the pumpkin roll which was a seasonal special. It was a creative roll that used a Japanese squash with a sweat aftertaste. We also ordered the spicy scallop nigiri and spicy scallop roll. The one weak point was the flavor of the spicy mayo. The spicy rolls weren't spicy at all and sometimes you just want a kick with your sushi. What's a spicy tuna roll if it isn't spicy?  Shiso is a great local spot and adds new creative rolls depending on the season. If they can bring the heat on the spicy mayo and continue offering excellent innovative rolls, Shiso can stand out amongst the sea of sushi restaurants in Chicago.

I've been on a real sushi kick lately. This does seem to be a theme for me lately, but so be it.  I had placed an order through their site the night before. I knew I was going to be in the area and needed some sushi.  I was in more of a crab mood, so I got myself two different crab orders. I got a king california maki and a piece of kani nigiri. The california roll was very good, but the crab meat wasn't completely doing it for me. The kani was a little disappointing as well.  The hamachi and salmon however were delicious. I can never really get enough of hamachi to begin with, but this was a real good cut. The salmon was perfect as well.  The shrimp dumplings were the real star for me though. Funny how that worked out. I got them steamed and they didn't last all too long for me.  The prices were pretty well in line with what I would expect from a sushi place. It didn't seem like there was the old town/near north side added tax along  with it. The sushi was good, but since I'm not in the area all too much I probably won't be here all too often
sushi was good tell them jeff sent you, they won't know what you are talking about

I went here for dinner last night and was disappointed. The food was very mediocre and overpriced. We tried three different dishes and none of them were particularly inspiring. I would not recommend this restaurant and will not be coming back again.

I would say this place was fair - 2.5 stars would be more how I felt.  Very under impressed with the spicy tuna app, but did enjoy the Mexican roll. Got tuna sashimi, didn't seem like a fresh piece of fish. Lastly, tried the chicken teriyaki dinner, it was not good. The chicken was very fatty dark meat, which if you're going to serve that, it would be nice to note on the menu so customers realize what is being served.  I found it inedible, and sent it back (still paid for it, though). Spicy miso soup was good, the Ginger dressing on the salad weird but ok, the tempura ice cream was terrific. UPDATE - I originally gave it three stars, but now knocked it down to one.  Remember that "not-so-fresh" tuna sashimi I mentioned?  Well, there were four in our party, another guy & I each got a couple of pieces of it, and both commented at the time that it was OK, but didn't taste very fresh.  Well, we both spent the next day hovering over toilets at our respective homes.   Neither of our wives, who didn't get the sashimi, got sick, but both of us did.  Will never go back.

We went to Shiso for my best friends birthday- they were very accommodating as we added to people at the last minute. The food was great and they were so kind as to store the cake I brought her in the back until the end as a surprise. It was also BYOB which is awesome!

Shiso is really all about location - it always seems to be near somewhere I need to go immediately following.  Aside from that, they take reservations and stick pretty well to them.  I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes to be seated.  The service is prompt but they don't bother you at all - since it's so small you can almost always call your server over. The sushi is good - creative but sometimes it's adorned with a little too much accoutrements.  My favorite is the Latin and the Volcano. Definitely make reservations!

It's an excellent neighborhood sushi place with very reasonable prices. The decor is simple but tasteful. The service was attentive and pleasant. It has a BYOB policy so that, in and of itself, dramatically lowers what you're going to spend for a nice dinner out.  Very good maki selection. We had the Mango Tango, excellent. The Latin, even better. And the Crunchy Spicy Tuna, more simple than the others but very well done. All in all, no complaints. I've lived a few blocks away for two years and have no idea why I haven't visited before. It will be a regular destination going forward.

God I love this place. And not just because I live 3 blocks away (ok that doesn't hurt). I have tried MANY sushi places in Chicago and this always ranks in the top 3 for me. First, they're BYOB because all great sushi places should be. And their rolls - delish. They're reasonably priced and all taste delicious. They have a great selection as well. The Shiso Signature roll is AMAZING. If you're a fan of miso soup, they have a spicy miso soup that is great - I've never  seen this on any other menu. Most importantly, the fish is always fresh. I'm not a fan of any of the cooked rolls, I always like raw fish and the fish is super fresh. I have never had anything questionable here like I have at many sushi places in the city. This place is small so if you want to come at 7 or 8pm on a weekend, be prepared to wait if you don't have a reservation. But I can guarantee the wait is worth it!

Never got my food.  Ordered sushi delivery. Driver called from the other side of the city.  I live a couple blocks away. After 30 more min, no sign of them.  Sushi had been riding around in a car for over an hour now. Who wants raw fish after its been in a car for hr.  Called again after having to explain why I wouldn't want hr old sushi, they offered to remake and send over, but I would have to wait normal delivery time.

During my Tour de BYOB I stumbled across this little neighborhood gem. I've lived next door for over a year but never made it in so I'm glad I finally managed. The service was super prompt, the menu is vast, and the sushi is really good. There wasn't a cork fee associated with our wine either, which is always a plus. Shiso seems to do pretty good business with take-out; there were people coming in regularly and walking out with to-go containers; a very novel idea in the event you don't want to take your B anywhere with you.
In few words I can describe Shiso cute little place with quick service, great food and very reasonable for the price.

Cute easy little spot, perfect for our before our show down the street at Zanies.  We made reservations for four at 6:30pm just to be sure we got in, but probably didn't need to - the place was relatively empty when we arrived. They were more than happy to place our sake and wine in their fridge until we were ready, and then it promptly appeared upon request. LOVE that Chicago has totally embraced BYOB. Everything we had was good, so it seems silly to detail it all here. Of particular note, however: mango tango maki - they're serious about the mango, and i love it takoyaki - baked japanese octopus puff - best eaten in one bite :) a first for me, surprisingly delicious. sushi supreme - loved the snapper (also new to me), loved the himachi (almost always do); you don't get to pick the maki roll, they pick it for you. we wound up with tuna - fine, but nothing outta this world. edamame - could have used another minute of boiling and a little more salt but we inhaled it all Fish was all fresh and generously cut. Yum, yum, I'd eat here before the next show, too!

a friend's pick for dinner ...  Pros - asked if we had reservations, we didn't; but seated us anyways - reasonable prices for sushi - rolls were good - I feel like the furt Cons - small joint - understaffed - waited a long time to order and get food Conclusion - Will return to try other rolls - how can this california girl say no to good sushi at reasonable prices?

Just ok from a vegetarian's perspective. Good selection and the sushi was good, but not spectacular. The server assured us the jalapeño miso soup is vegetarian, which I remain skeptical about, but we tried it anyway and it was ok. Nothing to write home about. The spicy yakisoba was sorely disappointing - noodles overcooked and mushy. The search for a good sushi place continues...

My favorite neighborhood sushi spot!! The sushi is always fresh and very reasonablly priced. The waitstaff is very friendly and its BYOB :) I would recommend making reservations for weekend nights..the place is tiny and fills up quickly!

I really enjoyed this little sushi place in Old Town. Great, quality sushi, great location and a quite, BYOB to catch up with a good friend :) I would recommend trying one of the many specials of the day!

I came here for a family style dinner with Grubwithus and definitely wasn't disappointed.  For apps, we had spicy tuna tempura, crispy calamari, and shumai, which were all good. My favorite was the calamari especially the honey wasabi sauce. For soups and salads, we got the wakame salad, Shiso house salad, and spicy miso soup. I never had spicy miso soup before, so I tried it out. Verdict = I really liked it. Nice kick at the end. I also enjoyed the wakame salad. I don't eat seaweed salads, but this one was tasty and I may order this next time. I thought the Shiso house salad was just okay. For the main course, i was amazed by the amount of food that came out. We had 8 maki rolls and a plate of assorted of sushi and sashimi. Everything was so good. When we were done with the sushi, I was ready for dessert, but was surprised when they brought out spicy shrimp udon, which reminded me of thai food. When dessert came, I was really full. They gave us two Banana Tempura a la modes, but each had a different flavor of ice cream. One with green tea and the other with vanilla. Fried banana and green tea ice cream = heaven. Definitely coming back here again and next time, I'm bringing a bottle of wine. BYOB here!

If you haven't gone to Shiso before, give it a shot because I don't think you will be disappointed.  It's good sushi and there aren't a lot of sushi places in that area.  The owners are very nice and the service is great.  They also take reservations if you call them, which not all BYOB places do. All of the food is reasonably priced and fresh.  I have only ordered a few things there that I did not like, namely anything with escholar in it, but that might not be Shiso's fault.  I wish they had a few more standard rolls to choose from because I don't usually order specialty rolls, but the selection is still vast.  Also, I get the chicken teriyaki bento box sometimes and it is very good and comes with a ton of food (soup, salad, california roll, tempura, rice) - if you are in the mood for it, you get a lot of bang for your buck.  The Kani Sunomo is also a very good salad if you like crab. If you are on the fence about going there, I say do it!

Byob is a plus, but bring the ear plugs...this places gets really loud when it's a full house (max 30 or so). Sushi was above par but the beef wrapped asparagus was nothing special.  Would have been better with a larger group.

Wow, great sushi. We had delivery and ventured away from Butterfly which is our normal delivery sushi place. This place is better but seemed a tad more expensive. The sushi rolls were a little smaller too but tasted much better than other joints. The quality of the rolls more than made up for the portions. This is my new go to sushi place for delivery.

I'm an idiot. I ordered delivery from this place and the total was $52.00 I gave them $60 inc tip, then saw a $3 delivery fee and they couldn't even supply chop sticks, napkins or soy sauce. So I tipped 25% for horrible service. Don't order from them.

Benihana, this is not. Great food, great service, cozy place.   I discovered this place a month ago, and went here with a group of friends. I was amazed with the variety of the menu. There's not too many places that give you quality food and a very reasonable price.  The real test came last week when I decided to celebrate my sister's birthday here, along with my parents and older sister. Being the sushi connoisseur that she is, I was glad that she echoed my sentiments after eating here.  Highly reccomend this place....and I wouldn't mind coming back here a third time either.

My go-to sushi spot to grab dinner before a night out in Old Town.  Pros: - BYO (no fee) - Cheap (for Old Town) - Accepts reservations - Good, fresh, and creative sushi - Spicy Miso (jalepenos, not just Sriracha) Cons: - A little small (could also be pro) - People "camp out" with their BYO booze way after dinner - Gets crowded and relatively loud

The best sushi I have had in a long, long time. We spotted this place a few weeks ago, while walking around the neighborhood, and decided to give it a try. We placed a take out order and could not have been more satisfied with our quiet Sushi Night . Great quality sushi and a creative menu!  Kudos to Shiso - we are fans and will definitely be back here soon!

Great sushi no matter what time of day you go. It is also a good place to save some money from BYOB. (Of course no liquor is allowed.)  The staff is always genuine and punctual. I have had most of their specialty and city rolls and have never been disappointed. They have very good fresh fish for sushi as well. One of the best parts is that they are open during lunch while many other Japanese restaurants in the area are not.  If your going for dinner I recommend making a reservation no matter the night just because it is a pretty small nook.
This was my second time trying Sushi in Chicago. The Sushi actually made me sick. I guess it was an ingredient that they use because at another Sushi place I had tried I didn't get sick.

I came back here last night and had a better experience. It was a good amount of people, but didn't have to wait for a table. The place got quiet at times and I felt like people around us were listening to our conversation since it's a tight place. BYOB with no corkage fee is nice. Tried a couple salads, the sashimi supreme (platter) and a roll with hamachi. Everything seemed good, but still nothing spectacular or out of the ordinary. Sorry. Our waitress was nice, but forgot to bring out my miso soup that comes with the platter.
A neighborhood favorite.  BYOB, delicious rolls (especially the volcano), and not too big or busy.  As others have mentioned, definitely a great date spot.

Had a fantastic dine in experience. BYOB with no corkage fee is basically my favorite thing ever.  The calamari roll is shockingly good. Also highly reccommend the Chicago roll. The fish is very fresh and tasty, and Shiso's menu is packed with a lot of really inventive non-raw rolls that are delicious. They are not something I would have ever ordered on my own, but I'm glad my friend did!  Restaurant is small but very cute. Very empty when we arrived at 6:45pm, but was PACKED by the time we left at 8:15ish. Tons of easy meter parking on North Ave.

One of my new favorite finds!  I finally dined in after ordering delivery a couple times. The restaurant is small but cozy and inviting. Read: Intimate. Perfect for date night. And as the other reviews indicate....the BYOB no corkage factor is a huge bonus! The Spicy Calamari Roll is simply FABULOUS. One of the best rolls I've had to date. I had to have 2. Now if they could just make it into the Sears Tower......jk. Just thinking about it makes me hungry all over again. Great value for the quality!

For a long time Cafe Sushi was the only BYOB sushi game in Old Town. I'm glad there are more BYOB options in this hood, especially BYOB sushi options. I wish they popped up when I lived a block away; although if they did, I'd might have gone broke or suffered "mercury toxicity" a la Jeremy Piven. Located on North Avenue, a few blocks west of Sedgwick, Shiso's storefront is easy to pass up, but a welcome addition to the sparse Old Town dining choices west of Wells. It was dead when we arrived and packed by the time we left about 90 minutes later on a Wednesday; I recommend reservations if you plan on dining at 7 or later. We started out with an order of edamame. Either we got a pretty generous serving or I was the only one in the party who was bananas over edamame. Shiso's sushi menu is quite robust; we ordered five rolls, which was perfect for our group of four. We ordered spicy tuna, rainbow, latin, dragon and shrimp tempura. I'm more partial rolls with only raw ingredients, but they all were good. I also gravitate toward simpler rolls, but found the spicy tuna only ok. They mince the tuna in this roll, which is a pet peeve of mine as I think you lose a lot of the fish taste. Service was very hands off. The restaurant was empty the first half of our meal, but our server wasn't really anywhere in sight. We had to flag her down both to place our order and get our check. Also, we were never offered an ice bucket to keep our second bottle of wine cold, yet the table that arrived later got one. It wasn't bad or even unfriendly service, just inattentive. Our bill for 4 people was $18 each including tip, which I thought was pretty reasonable. Considering it's also BYOB without any corking fee, it felt like a steal. Cafe Sushi is still my preferred BYOB destination in Old Town, but I'd definitely make a return visit here or carry out; it's actually quite convenient from the Brown Line and #11 bus. 3.5 stars
Solid, small sushi joint that uses fresh seafood brought to you by nice waiters and waitresses. If you're hungry and in the neighborhood, it's worth a try.

Me so like Shiso!  My fellow brides-to-be and I were out doing what we do best, pampering ourselves and gabbing about the stresses of wedding planning (our lives are so strenuous, we know), when the hunger for sushi struck, as it so often does after a mani/pedi.  Bride #1 happened to have a bottle of white in her purse, the stresses of planning the big deal can be taxing, so off we headed to Shiso, where the miso is fabuliso! I don't know... I'm kind of in a rhyming place right now..? Anyway we had our favorite, escolar sashimi, and a variety of specialty rolls and an appetizer of edamame. All that yumminess came to just $16/bride. And that's with tip! I think I spent more on my lunch that day... However waters went unfilled often, and our edamame was snatched off of the table more than once when we weren't finished. Keep those mitts off our food until we're finished, please! This is a lovely place for a gathering of friends, and the menu is A-Okay, hooray! (I'm finished rhyming now. I apologize.)

As if BYOB and sushi were not good enough on their own when you put them together the combination is SUSHI-O-TASTIC ! Shiso is just steps from the Browline Sedgwick stop though there is a lot of meter parking available on NorthAve if public transpo is not your thing. Like most sushi places Shiso is small but it didn't really get busy until around 8:30pm, definitley make reservations if you are that forward thinking. SAKE SAKE SAKE.... it got pretty loud in Shiso mainly in thanks to the table banging saki bombing group next to us. There were 4 girls and we each ordered 2 things to split, we left full but not stuffed and at $80 or $20 each that is a steal of a sushi deal! (no corkage fee) Reccomendations:  + Calamari (loved the honey mustard dipping sauce)  + Forver Maki (shapped like a heart aw, though definitley a two bitter, so heavy it was hard to actually pick up with the chop sticks) + Sears Tower (great presentaion, cant' go wrong with warm cream cheese) + Philly, Chicago, Latin, Crunchy Spicy Tuna... ect. All DELICIOUS. I have become quite the sushi conesoiur and Shiso is definitley on the top of my list. Inventive rolls, great prices, really fresh fish and the best part is everything is rolled tight so they do not fall apart which sadly is not always the case. If only my water glass was filled up more... I could have stayed hydrated. Hydrated = Happy.

After passing by this place over the last two years of living in Old Town, I FINALLY gave it a shot.  I wasn't disappointed. The atmosphere was very cozy with very minimalist/simple decor. My friend and I wanted a light meal so we ordered the edamame and three rolls - Dragon, Spicy Tuna, and the Chicago.  The Spicy Tuna and Dragon were average.  The Chicago was pretty tasty. Of course, I couldn't pass up dessert.  My friend had the vanilla ice cream (can't screw that up!) and I had the green tea mochi.  The mochi presentation was creative - two mochi cut into fourths with a squirt of whipped cream in the middle of each mochi, topped with a cherry.  With chocolate sauce on the platter, it satisfied my craving for sweets. Service was attentive and helpful.  Points for keeping my water glass full! We didn't take advantage of the BYOB option, but I will remember that for next time. With this place only a hop, skip, and a jump away, I will definitely be back.

This is one of my favorite sushi places in the city! Try the sears tower.  It is one of the best sushi rolls i have ever had! Also, they have this fried banana dessert that is awesome! And it is byob!!
